body:
There is two conflicting things, if the install command is inplace, distutils.core works better because things are copied to the right inplace folder.

If install by user seems setuptools works better. Maybe we should find a better way to solve this problem
The current speech demo breaks by a bug in clip gradient setting. We are going to fix it very soon.

I wasn't actually running it, I was just looking at the reported numbers.
I suspect you guys may have looked at, and copied, the Kaldi AMI scripts about a year ago, and maybe the results were a lot worse at that time.
Thanks for pointing out it. Let's sync with @pluskid @yzhang87
@danpovey, yeah, the AMI scripts was a year ago. I noticed it is much better now but haven't sync with it.

There are many changes that will improve your numbers, but also changes to
our nnet training that will improve our numbers.. it will make the
comparison much more meaningful if you switch over to using the newer
recipes.

Thanks for point out! We were waiting for the NNVM support for RNN. Will update the whole things soon.
Sorry that I've misinterpreted the question. The example is not for the distributed environment. But I think we can achieve such pipeline using the current KVStore/Executor APIs.

multi machine model parallel is doable with low level api (executor+kvstore), but with modern gpus it's usually unnecessarily complicated and under performing except maybe for very special cases. Recommendation system & matrix factorization is one such case. I suggest you talk with @xlvector if you are interested
You can catch the error, append name and re throw in infer_shape_pass I think.
@piiswrong Sorry, I didn't notice there is a separate doc for adding caffe plugin. Thank you for you reference.

fixed. add pad=(2,2) at first conv layer. 
 https://github.com/guolinke/deep-learning-benchmarks/blob/master/mxnet/models/alexnet.py#L15

@Darwin2011 Yes, this is a problem. One way to deal with the problem is to add `pad=(1,1)` for lower level pooling layers like here (https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/image-classification/symbol_inception-bn-28-small.py#L19-L20). However, we may need to fine-tune the network again since the pooling function has been changed.
BTW, have you tested if the pooling layer works well for the `SAME` mode?

@magic282 We can simply do nothing in the backward path of the argmax operator. We can register it as output node.

@piiswrong @Darwin2011 @sxjscience: These names are really bad. In the literature, 'same', 'valid' and 'full' have precise meanings for pooling and convolutions:
- same: the tensor is padded so that the input and output tensors are the same width and height. 
- valid: no padding

This is used by [TensorFlow](https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/r0.10/api_docs/python/nn.html#convolution) or [Numpy](http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.convolve.html), for example. Using these names for this will cause confusion (esp. if MXnet decided to add these very useful options for convolution + pooling).

One option: have a "caffe_compatibility" (bool) option. 

Here is a question that we should answer first: what is the actual computational difference in the pooling layer? Is the MXNet pooling layer equivalent to Caffe with some extra padding for certain input dimensions? If so, we can fix this at the Caffe importer level rather than hacking it into the MXNet pooling definition.
@pluskid Thank you! I can create a new model using internal symbols and parameters.
I think you are looking for `MXNDArraySyncCopyFromCPU` and `MXNDArraySyncCopyToCPU` in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/c_api/c_api.cc

I have the same issue. Each of my node has an Ethernet interface eno1 and an Infiniband interface ib0. I want to use ib0, but the launcher always binds to ethernet eno1.

I am using two nodes node001 and node002. The eno1 address of node001 is 10.141.0.1 and its ib0 address is 10.149.0.1. he eno1 address of node002 is 10.141.0.2 and its ib0 address is 10.149.0.2. I executed the launch.py directly from node001. The hosts file contains
10.149.0.1
10.149.0.2

I used the following command:
$ export DMLC_INTERFACE=ib0
$ ../../launch.py -H hosts -n 2 --launcher ssh python train_imagenet.py ...

But the log still shows both nodes are using their ethernet address eno1 instead of ib0. 

What is the correct way to bind to the correct infiniband interface? Thanks.

@piiswrong @tqchen @antinucleon I've moved the testing functions to the main package so the user can directly call these functions to check their own operator.

I tried sync, but the performance was worse.
I tried the following combinations:
1. kv-store=dist_sync
No matter what addresses are specified in hosts file (ethernet or infiniband addresses), both nodes node[0] and node[1] have the speed ~343 sample/sec
1. kv-store=dist_async
   No matter what addresses are specified in hosts file (ethernet or infiniband addresses), node[0] has the speed 740 samples/sec,  node[1] has the speed ~343 sample/sec

No matter from what node I executed the launch.py, the performance on node[0] and node[1] is the same as the performance I executed from another node.
So does it mean if I execute the program from node001, node[0] is node001 and node[1] is node002.
and if I execute the program from node002, node[0] is node002 and node[1] is node001?

I tried to let the program use infiniband address. As I asked in another question, you told me to put "export DMLC_INTERFACCE=ib0" between launch.py and training script:
../../tools/launch.py -H hosts -n 2 --launcher ssh export DMLC_INTERFACE=ib0; python     train_imagenet.py --network inception-bn --gpus 0,1,2,3 --batch-size 256 --num-epochs 1 --data-shape 224 --data-dir ../../data/ilsvrc12/ --kv-store dist_async

then it has the following error:
mxnet/dmlc-core/include/dmlc/logging.h:235: [12:26:17] src/postoffice.cc:16: Check  notnull: Environment::Get()->find("DMLC_NUM_WORKER")

Then I tried to specify DMLC_NUM_WORKER, but it asked for more environment variables. So I specified all of them:
../../tools/launch.py -H hosts -n 2 --launcher ssh export DMLC_INTERFACE=ib0; export DMLC_NUM_WORKER=2; export DMLC_NUM_SERVER=2; export DMLC_ROLE=worker; python     train_imagenet.py --network inception-bn --gpus 0,1,2,3 --batch-size 256 --num-epochs 1 --data-shape 224 --data-dir ../../data/ilsvrc12/ --kv-store dist_async

but again has the following error:
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'std::logic_error'
  6   what():  basic_string::_S_construct null not valid
  7 ./run.sh: line 18: 36014 Aborted                 python train_imagenet.py --network inception-bn --gpus 0,1,2,3 --batch-size 256 --num-epochs 1 --data-shape 224 --data    -dir ../../data/ilsvrc12/ --kv-store dist_async

The errors are the same if I use dist_sync instead of dist_async.

So how to utilize another network interface correctly and how to get the scalable performance when using multiple nodes?

There is a bug with the current version of the library. If you roll back to an older version, previosly to this [PR](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/2585), then it is working. I used the commit `c3edd8d75c0b9221c2a808da9b755fad1e27249e` and it is working. There is a difference in inception-bn with the padding:
Old one:
`pooling = mx.symbol.Pooling(data=data, kernel=(3, 3), stride=(2, 2), pool_type="max", name=('max_pool_%s_pool' % name))`
[New](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/image-classification/symbol_inception-bn.R#L64) one:
`pooling = mx.symbol.Pooling(data=data, kernel=(3, 3), stride=(2, 2), pad=(1, 1), pool_type="max", name=('max_pool_%s_pool' % name))`
There might be other differences affecting the imagenet computing since the commit is very old. This might be related to this [issue](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/3359).
Thanks for pointing out the typo!

I think this is a legit change.
Although test_utils may be a better name
I observe that the memory pool reserve is working so there is no reason for rcnn testing to fail due to oom.
Any guidance on this would be very welcome. Any suggestions? Thx
How about try something simpler like l2-loss as MakeLoss(square(fc - label)) and see if other components of this learning process is affecting performance?

I tried square loss and it doesn't work. This is another test and doesn't work as well.
with lro <- mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(fc1)
sqrt(mean((preds-test.y)^2)) = 7.800502
